items.title: Live: Hamas hands over seven surviving hostages to Red Cross, Israel says
items.standfirst: Hamas on Monday released a first batch of seven surviving Israeli hostages to the Red Cross, said the Israeli army, marking the start of a hostage-prisoner swap under the first phase of a Gaza ceasefire deal brokered by President Donald Trump. The US leader declared the Gaza was “over” as he flew to the region as world leaders gather for a summit in Egypt. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.
items.content: Hamas on Monday released a first batch of seven surviving Israeli hostages to the Red Cross, said the Israeli army, marking the start of a hostage-prisoner swap under the first phase of a Gaza ceasefire deal brokered by President Donald Trump. The US leader declared the Gaza was “over” as he flew to the region as world leaders gather for a summit in Egypt. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

items.title: Trump says ‘war is over’ in Gaza as Israel awaits release of hostages
items.standfirst: US president says Middle East will ‘normalize’ before he boarded flight to Israel for world leaders’ peace summitThe war in Gaza has ended and the Middle East is going to “normalize”, Donald Trump said on Sunday as he flew to Israel, which was waiting for Hamas to release Israeli hostages as world leaders were gathering to discuss the next steps toward peace.“The war is over, you understand that,” Trump told reporters onboard Air Force One as he began a flight from Washington DC to Israel. Continue reading...
items.content: US president says Middle East will ‘normalize’ before he boarded flight to Israel for world leaders’ peace summitThe war in Gaza has ended and the Middle East is going to “normalize”, Donald Trump said on Sunday as he flew to Israel, which was waiting for Hamas to release Israeli hostages as world leaders were gathering to discuss the next steps toward peace.“The war is over, you understand that,” Trump told reporters onboard Air Force One as he began a flight from Washington DC to Israel. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel expects all 20 living hostages to be freed from Gaza on Monday morning
items.standfirst: Government says it is also preparing for release of 2,000 Palestinian detainees in crucial next phase of ceasefire dealGaza ceasefire live: follow all the latest updatesThe Israeli government says it expects all living hostages held in Gaza to be released on Monday morning and that it is preparing for the release of about 2,000 Palestinian detainees, the crucial next phase of the ceasefire deal that could end the two-year war in Gaza.“We are expecting all 20 of our living hostages to be released together at one time to the Red Cross and transported among six to eight vehicles,” said the Israeli government spokesperson Shosh Bedrosian. Continue reading...
items.content: Government says it is also preparing for release of 2,000 Palestinian detainees in crucial next phase of ceasefire dealGaza ceasefire live: follow all the latest updatesThe Israeli government says it expects all living hostages held in Gaza to be released on Monday morning and that it is preparing for the release of about 2,000 Palestinian detainees, the crucial next phase of the ceasefire deal that could end the two-year war in Gaza.“We are expecting all 20 of our living hostages to be released together at one time to the Red Cross and transported among six to eight vehicles,” said the Israeli government spokesperson Shosh Bedrosian. Continue reading...

items.content: President Trump departed for the Middle East ahead of the release of 20 living hostages held in Gaza. NBC News' chief foreign correspondent, Richard Engel, reports from Tel Aviv on the Israeli reaction to the ceasefire deal.

items.title: Trump to meet with families of hostages in Jerusalem
items.standfirst: NBC News’ Peter Alexander details President Donald Trump’s schedule as he heads to Israel after Hamas pledged to release Israeli hostages. Trump will meet with the families of hostages in Jerusalem before he heads to Egypt for a Middle East peace summit.
items.content: NBC News’ Peter Alexander details President Donald Trump’s schedule as he heads to Israel after Hamas pledged to release Israeli hostages. Trump will meet with the families of hostages in Jerusalem before he heads to Egypt for a Middle East peace summit.

items.title: Why does Israel arrest thousands of Palestinians?
items.standfirst: Israel has agreed to release many Palestinian prisoners as the ceasefire holds.
items.content: Israel has agreed to release many Palestinian prisoners as the ceasefire holds.

items.title: Israel says hostages will be freed from Gaza 'in a few hours' as ceasefire holds
items.standfirst: All living hostages held in the Gaza Strip will be released early Monday morning as part of a breakthrough ceasefire deal with Hamas, Israel said on Sunday, as Palestinians awaited the release of hundreds of prisoners held in Israel. US President Donald Trump, who will arrive Monday morning in Israel, will meet with families of the hostages and speak at the Knesset, Israel’s parliament.
items.content: All living hostages held in the Gaza Strip will be released early Monday morning as part of a breakthrough ceasefire deal with Hamas, Israel said on Sunday, as Palestinians awaited the release of hundreds of prisoners held in Israel. US President Donald Trump, who will arrive Monday morning in Israel, will meet with families of the hostages and speak at the Knesset, Israel’s parliament.

items.title: Hostage exchange in Gaza offers hope to prisoners’ families
items.standfirst: A stone's throw from the wall separating Israel and the occupied West Bank, the Shamasneh family is ready to welcome home two sons jailed for the past 34 years. Abdel Jawad and Mohammed are expected to be among the Palestinians freed from Israeli detention under the terms of the ceasefire agreement approved last week.
items.content: A stone's throw from the wall separating Israel and the occupied West Bank, the Shamasneh family is ready to welcome home two sons jailed for the past 34 years. Abdel Jawad and Mohammed are expected to be among the Palestinians freed from Israeli detention under the terms of the ceasefire agreement approved last week.

ai_summary: Donald Trump arrived in Israel as part of the Gaza ceasefire deal implementation.
Hamas began releasing hostages as part of the agreement brokered by the United States.
Seven Israeli hostages were released and crossed the border into Israel.
Trump credited Qatar for its role in the Gaza war ceasefire.
Stocks rose and fell when Trump gave the word, according to CNBC.

clusters.title: Border clashes between Afghanistan and Pakistan leave dozens dead
clusters.neutral_headline: Border Clashes Between Afghanistan and Pakistan Leave Dozens Dead

items.title: Border clashes between Afghanistan and Pakistan leave dozens dead
items.standfirst: Afghanistan and Pakistan said on Sunday they killed dozens of each other's troops during a night of heavy border clashes between the two countries. Afghanistan's Taliban forces launched attacks on Pakistani troops along their shared border late on Saturday, in what it called "retaliation for air strikes carried out by the Pakistani army on Kabul" on Thursday.
items.content: Afghanistan and Pakistan said on Sunday they killed dozens of each other's troops during a night of heavy border clashes between the two countries. Afghanistan's Taliban forces launched attacks on Pakistani troops along their shared border late on Saturday, in what it called "retaliation for air strikes carried out by the Pakistani army on Kabul" on Thursday.

items.title: Taliban and Pakistani forces exchange heavy fire across Afghanistan border
items.standfirst: Deadly clashes erupted overnight between the Taliban and Pakistani forces across the Afghanistan border.
items.content: Deadly clashes erupted overnight between the Taliban and Pakistani forces across the Afghanistan border.

items.title: Dozens killed in Pakistan-Afghanistan border clashes
items.standfirst: Dozens of fighters were killed in overnight border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan, both sides said on Sunday, in the most serious fighting between the neighbours since the Taliban came to power in Kabul. FRANCE 24's Shahzaib Wahlah reports from Islamabad.
items.content: Dozens of fighters were killed in overnight border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan, both sides said on Sunday, in the most serious fighting between the neighbours since the Taliban came to power in Kabul. FRANCE 24's Shahzaib Wahlah reports from Islamabad.

items.title: Heavy clashes erupt along Pakistan-Afghanistan border
items.standfirst: Escalation comes after Pakistani airstrike in Kabul, with Taliban launching reprisals against military postsIntense clashes erupted along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border on Saturday night, after an attack by the Afghan Taliban on Pakistani military posts led to a heavy exchange of fire and reportedly left dozens of soldiers dead.According to officials, Afghan troops opened fire on Pakistani army posts along the north-western border with Pakistan on Saturday night and seized several of the posts. The attacks came after the Taliban regime in Afghanistan accused Pakistan of carrying out airstrikes on Afghan territory, including in the capital, Kabul, earlier this week. Continue reading...
items.content: Escalation comes after Pakistani airstrike in Kabul, with Taliban launching reprisals against military postsIntense clashes erupted along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border on Saturday night, after an attack by the Afghan Taliban on Pakistani military posts led to a heavy exchange of fire and reportedly left dozens of soldiers dead.According to officials, Afghan troops opened fire on Pakistani army posts along the north-western border with Pakistan on Saturday night and seized several of the posts. The attacks came after the Taliban regime in Afghanistan accused Pakistan of carrying out airstrikes on Afghan territory, including in the capital, Kabul, earlier this week. Continue reading...

items.title: Afghan Taliban says Pakistani troops killed in 'retaliatory' border attacks
items.standfirst: The attacks came days after Pakistan was accused of bombing a market inside Afghanistan.
items.content: The attacks came days after Pakistan was accused of bombing a market inside Afghanistan.

items.title: Afghanistan says it has killed 58 Pakistani soldiers in overnight border operations
items.standfirst: Afghanistan said Sunday it killed 58 Pakistani soldiers in overnight border operations, in response to what it called repeated violations of its territory and airspace.
items.content: Afghanistan said Sunday it killed 58 Pakistani soldiers in overnight border operations, in response to what it called repeated violations of its territory and airspace.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Pakistani, Afghan forces exchange deadly border fire: What’s next?
items.standfirst: Afghan officials say 58 Pakistani soldiers killed while Pakistan says 200 Taliban and affiliated 'terrorists' dead.
items.content: Afghan officials say 58 Pakistani soldiers killed while Pakistan says 200 Taliban and affiliated 'terrorists' dead.

items.title: Pakistan closes border with Afghanistan after dozens killed in overnight clashes
items.standfirst: Pakistan closed all border crossings with Afghanistan on Sunday after deadly overnight clashes in which both sides claimed to have killed dozens of troops. Islamabad regularly accuses the Taliban administration in Kabul of harbouring militants who attack Pakistan, a charge Afghan officials deny.
items.content: Pakistan closed all border crossings with Afghanistan on Sunday after deadly overnight clashes in which both sides claimed to have killed dozens of troops. Islamabad regularly accuses the Taliban administration in Kabul of harbouring militants who attack Pakistan, a charge Afghan officials deny.

ai_summary: Afghanistan and Pakistan reported dozens of casualties in border clashes.
The Taliban launched attacks on Pakistani troops along the shared border.
Pakistan was accused of airstrikes on Afghan territory earlier in the week.
The clashes are the most serious fighting since the Taliban took power.
Afghanistan claimed to have killed 58 Pakistani soldiers in the fighting.

clusters.title: Madagascar president says coup under way as soldiers join protesters
clusters.neutral_headline: Madagascar President Says Coup Underway as Soldiers Join Protesters

items.title: Madagascar president says coup under way as soldiers join protesters
items.standfirst: The president of Madagascar Andry Rajoelina has claimed a coup is under way after weeks of intense youth-led protests.

items.content: Soldiers join mass antigovernment protests, urging no violence, as unrest over shortages and political divisions grows.

items.title: Madagascar’s president says illegal power grab by military is under way
items.standfirst: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit have announced they are taking over after weeks of youth-led protestsMadagascar’s president said an “attempt to seize power illegally and by force” was under way, as an elite military unit that joined protesters on the streets on Saturday announced it was taking over the army.The Capsat unit’s intervention comes after weeks of youth-led protests, which started on 25 September against water and electricity shortages and expanded to calling for the resignation of the president, Andry Rajoelina, an end to corruption and radical overhaul of the political system. Continue reading...
items.content: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit have announced they are taking over after weeks of youth-led protestsMadagascar’s president said an “attempt to seize power illegally and by force” was under way, as an elite military unit that joined protesters on the streets on Saturday announced it was taking over the army.The Capsat unit’s intervention comes after weeks of youth-led protests, which started on 25 September against water and electricity shortages and expanded to calling for the resignation of the president, Andry Rajoelina, an end to corruption and radical overhaul of the political system. Continue reading...

items.title: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit join protests against Madagascar’s president
items.standfirst: Demonstrators march alongside regiment, who earlier in the day said they would not fire on the crowdsMadagascar’s prime minister called for calm after an elite group of soldiers joined thousands of protesters against the country’s president on the streets of the capital on Saturday afternoon.Protesters marched alongside soldiers from the Capsat unit, who drove armoured vehicles, some waving Madagascar flags, from their base in Soanierana in the south of Antananarivo. Continue reading...
items.content: Demonstrators march alongside regiment, who earlier in the day said they would not fire on the crowdsMadagascar’s prime minister called for calm after an elite group of soldiers joined thousands of protesters against the country’s president on the streets of the capital on Saturday afternoon.Protesters marched alongside soldiers from the Capsat unit, who drove armoured vehicles, some waving Madagascar flags, from their base in Soanierana in the south of Antananarivo. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The President of Madagascar claimed a coup was underway.
An army unit declared support for anti-government protests.
Soldiers from an elite unit announced they were taking over the army.
Protests started over shortages and expanded to call for the President's resignation.
The Prime Minister called for calm after soldiers joined the protests.

items.title: ‘Lab to fab’: are promises of a graphene revolution finally coming true?
items.standfirst: Two decades after the material was first produced, some UK firms have reaped its potential but others are strugglingAfter graphene was first produced at the University of Manchester in 2004, it was hailed as a wonder material, stronger than steel but lighter than paper. But two decades on, not every UK graphene company has made the most of that potential. Some show promise but others are struggling.Extracted from graphite, commonly used in pencils, graphene is a latticed sheet of carbon one atom thick, and is highly effective at conducting heat and electricity. China is the world’s biggest producer, using it to try to get ahead in the global race to produce microchips and in sectors such as construction. Continue reading...
items.content: Two decades after the material was first produced, some UK firms have reaped its potential but others are strugglingAfter graphene was first produced at the University of Manchester in 2004, it was hailed as a wonder material, stronger than steel but lighter than paper. But two decades on, not every UK graphene company has made the most of that potential. Some show promise but others are struggling.Extracted from graphite, commonly used in pencils, graphene is a latticed sheet of carbon one atom thick, and is highly effective at conducting heat and electricity. China is the world’s biggest producer, using it to try to get ahead in the global race to produce microchips and in sectors such as construction. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Graphene was hailed as a wonder material two decades ago.
Some UK firms have reaped the potential of graphene.
Graphene is a latticed sheet of carbon one atom thick.
China is the world's biggest producer of graphene.
Not every UK graphene company has succeeded.

items.title: Most of Great Britain’s major rail operators are back in public hands – is it working?
items.standfirst: Explore the Guardian’s tracker to see which operators are nationalised and if services are improving under public ownershipThe majority of Great Britain’s major rail operators are now in public ownership, as the Labour government continues its efforts to make the railways “more reliable, affordable and accessible”.The nationalisation of Greater Anglia on 12 October represents the ninth major passenger service to be brought back into public ownership, leaving seven to go before the government’s deadline of completing every operator by 2027. Continue reading...
items.content: Explore the Guardian’s tracker to see which operators are nationalised and if services are improving under public ownershipThe majority of Great Britain’s major rail operators are now in public ownership, as the Labour government continues its efforts to make the railways “more reliable, affordable and accessible”.The nationalisation of Greater Anglia on 12 October represents the ninth major passenger service to be brought back into public ownership, leaving seven to go before the government’s deadline of completing every operator by 2027. Continue reading...

The Labour government aims to make railways more reliable.

The government's deadline for completion is 2027.

clusters.title: Live: Reinstated French PM’s new govt takes office as budget pressure intensifies
clusters.neutral_headline: French Government Faces Budget Deadline and Political Turmoil

items.title: Live: Reinstated French PM’s new govt takes office as budget pressure intensifies
items.standfirst: Reinstated French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s new government takes office on Monday amid mounting pressure to urgently produce a budget and quell political turmoil that is scaring businesses and investors and staining the country’s image. Lecornu will now also have to seek compromises to avoid an immediate no-confidence vote in the National Assembly. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.
items.content: Reinstated French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s new government takes office on Monday amid mounting pressure to urgently produce a budget and quell political turmoil that is scaring businesses and investors and staining the country’s image. Lecornu will now also have to seek compromises to avoid an immediate no-confidence vote in the National Assembly. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.

items.title: France’s Macron unveils new government ahead of budget deadline
items.standfirst: The new government, led by Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu, must present a 2026 draft budget on Monday.
items.content: The new government, led by Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu, must present a 2026 draft budget on Monday.

items.title: French PM Lecornu names new government before looming budget deadline
items.standfirst: Reinstated French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu named a new government Sunday after a meeting with President Emmanuel Macron, as he faces pressure to urgently produce a budget and quell the political turmoil engulfing France. It is unclear how long this new team, which includes several old faces and some new, will last.
items.content: Reinstated French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu named a new government Sunday after a meeting with President Emmanuel Macron, as he faces pressure to urgently produce a budget and quell the political turmoil engulfing France. It is unclear how long this new team, which includes several old faces and some new, will last.

items.title: French PM Lecornu races against the clock to form govt cabinet
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu faces a race against time to form a government by Monday's budget deadline, as divisions emerged within the conservative Les Republicains party over whether to accept ministerial posts in his cabinet. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot reports from Paris.
items.content: French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu faces a race against time to form a government by Monday's budget deadline, as divisions emerged within the conservative Les Republicains party over whether to accept ministerial posts in his cabinet. items.title: New Jersey declares state of emergency as nor’easter approaches
items.standfirst: Airports post delays and cancellations in advance of anticipated coastal flooding and strong windsA nor’easter churned its way up the east coast on Sunday, with New Jersey declaring a state of emergency and some airports posting delays and cancellations in advance of anticipated coastal flooding and strong winds, as another storm system struck farther south with heavy rain and flooding.“The greatest effects are going to be the coastal flooding potential, especially for areas from north-eastern North Carolina northward to much of the New Jersey coast,” said meteorologist Bob Oravec with the National Weather Service in College Park, Maryland. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Cameroon holds presidential elections with incumbent Biya poised for 8th term
clusters.neutral_headline: Cameroon Holds Presidential Elections with Incumbent Biya

items.title: Cameroon holds presidential elections with incumbent Biya poised for 8th term
items.standfirst: Voters cast their ballots Sunday in Cameroon's presidential elections, which 92-year-old Paul Biya, the world's oldest serving head of state, is expected to win, extending his already 43-year grip on power. Biya faces 11 opponents, including former employment minister Issa Tchiroma Bakary, 79, who has generated unexpected enthusiasm among voters in the central African nation, where half the population is under 20. FRANCE 24's Indira Eteng reports from Yaoundé.
items.content: Voters cast their ballots Sunday in Cameroon's presidential elections, which 92-year-old Paul Biya, the world's oldest serving head of state, is expected to win, extending his already 43-year grip on power. Biya faces 11 opponents, including former employment minister Issa Tchiroma Bakary, 79, who has generated unexpected enthusiasm among voters in the central African nation, where half the population is under 20. FRANCE 24's Indira Eteng reports from Yaoundé.

items.title: Cameroon’s 92-year-old president set for another term as country goes to polls
items.standfirst: Paul Biya, in power since 1982, has brushed off calls to retire but is rarely seen in publicCameroon goes to the polls on Sunday for a presidential election with Paul Biya, already the world’s oldest head of state at the age of 92, the favourite to win an eighth term in power in the central African country.A fractured opposition of 11 candidates is standing against Biya, who, despite his advanced age and declining health, has dismissed calls for him to retire. Continue reading...
items.content: Paul Biya, in power since 1982, has brushed off calls to retire but is rarely seen in publicCameroon goes to the polls on Sunday for a presidential election with Paul Biya, already the world’s oldest head of state at the age of 92, the favourite to win an eighth term in power in the central African country.A fractured opposition of 11 candidates is standing against Biya, who, despite his advanced age and declining health, has dismissed calls for him to retire. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Cameroon held presidential elections on Sunday.
Paul Biya, 92, is expected to win an eighth term.
Biya has been in power for 43 years.
He faces 11 opponents in the election.
A former minister is generating unexpected voter enthusiasm.
